title: Insider believes Red Sox have ‘another move in them’ this offseason to improve infield
author: Conor Roche
bullets: ESPN's Jeff Passan suggests a potential trade for infield help as Red Sox prepare for the 2026 season.
Potential trade targets include Isaac Paredes of Houston and Christian Walker, though Walker may not fit team's needs.
Red Sox exploring internal options with Marcelo Mayer at third base, Romy Gonzalez and David Hamilton at second.

title: Even Drake Maye’s dad is surprised by Patriots’ Super Bowl run
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Drake Maye's father, Mark Maye, didn't expect the Patriots to reach Super Bowl LX after back-to-back 4-13 seasons.
Drake Maye led the NFL in completion percentage (72%) and passer rating (113.5) during the regular season, boosting Patriots' performance.
Maye struggled in the postseason, with a 55.8% completion rate as Patriots secured a 10-7 AFC title win over the Broncos.

title: That guy on TV, Cris Collinsworth, will look familiar to Patriots fans tuning into NBC to watch the Super Bowl
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Cris Collinsworth, alongside Mike Tirico, will call Super Bowl LX on NBC featuring the Patriots versus the Seahawks.
Collinsworth has broadcast five Super Bowls involving the Patriots, including their previous face-off with the Seahawks 11 seasons ago.
Collinsworth has covered three pivotal Patriots games this season, witnessing their diverse game strategies and victories.

title: Mass. snowplow driver who spotted legs sticking out of snowbank praised for saving older man
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Matte McGarry, a snowplow driver, rescued an older man stuck in a snowbank on Burnett Street, Auburn.
The man, initially believed to be an illusion, was found face-down and struggling after a winter storm.
McGarry is set to receive a commendation from the Auburn Board of Selectmen for his life-saving actions.

title: UMass student suspended after organizing protest sues university
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: UMass Amherst junior Kivlighan de Montebello sues the university over a one-year suspension for organizing a protest.
The protest targeted RTX's recruitment efforts at a career fair, alleging their technology's use in Gaza by Israel.
De Montebello argues his First Amendment rights were violated; the lawsuit seeks a jury trial, damages, and suspension expungement.

title: More details emerge about children charged with murder in R.I.
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Four preteens were charged with murder for the January 19 fatal beating of 51-year-old Rony Alonso in Providence.
The juveniles, three aged 12 and one aged 11, were caught after a subsequent rock-throwing incident on January 20.
Initial charges of felony assault were upgraded to murder after Alonso died on January 22 from blunt force trauma injuries.

title: Allandale Farm loses second Highland steer following brother’s death last year
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Curtis, a 16-year-old Highland steer at Allandale Farm, died peacefully, a year after his brother Willard's passing.
Allandale Farm in Jamaica Plain, Boston's only working farm, was Curtis's home since 2008 along with his brother Willard.
Condolences flooded in for Curtis, who was cherished by the community for providing comfort during challenging times like COVID.

title: Red Sox have reportedly discussed trading reliever Jordan Hicks in search of an infielder
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Red Sox are considering trading reliever Jordan Hicks to acquire an infielder before the new season.
Boston's starters Brayan Bello and Patrick Sandoval have also surfaced in trade discussions.
Cubs' Nico Hoerner and Astros' Isaac Paredes are potential infield targets for the Red Sox.

title: Breakout Patriots LB K’Lavon Chaisson wants to re-sign with New England in free agency
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Linebacker K'Lavon Chaisson intends to re-sign with the New England Patriots during the upcoming free agency period.
Chaisson had a standout season with 7.5 sacks, 18 QB hits, and two forced fumbles, aiding the Patriots' defense.
Chaisson credits coordinators Josh McDaniels and Zak Kuhr for maximizing team performance and reaching the Super Bowl.

title: Patriots DC Terrell Williams declared cancer-free after four months battling prostate cancer
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Patriots Defensive Coordinator Terrell Williams declared cancer-free after four months of treatment for aggressive prostate cancer.
Williams was diagnosed in September; cancer had spread to multiple areas before effective treatment at Mass General Hospital.
Patriots head coach Mike Vrabel announced Williams' recovery to players ahead of the divisional playoff win against the Texans.
